1.text: My son! if thou hast been surety for thy friend, Hast stricken for a stranger thy hand,

2.text: Hast been snared with sayings of thy mouth, Hast been captured with sayings of thy mouth,

3.text: Do this now, my son, and be delivered, For thou hast come into the hand of thy friend. Go, trample on thyself, and strengthen thy friend,

4.text: Give not sleep to thine eyes, And slumber to thine eyelids,

5.text: Be delivered as a roe from the hand, And as a bird from the hand of a fowler.

6.text: Go unto the ant, O slothful one, See her ways and be wise;

7.text: Which hath not captain, overseer, and ruler,

8.text: She doth prepare in summer her bread, She hath gathered in harvest her food.

9.text: Till when, O slothful one, dost thou lie? When dost thou arise from thy sleep?

10.text: A little sleep, a little slumber, A little clasping of the hands to rest,

11.text: And thy poverty hath come as a traveller, And thy want as an armed man.

12.text: A man of worthlessness, a man of iniquity, Walking with perverseness of mouth,

13.text: Winking with his eyes, speaking with his feet, Directing with his fingers,

14.text: Frowardness is in his heart, devising evil at all times, Contentions he sendeth forth.

15.text: Therefore suddenly cometh his calamity, Instantly he is broken—and no healing.

16.text: These six hath Jehovah hated, Yea, seven are abominations to His soul.

17.text: Eyes high—tongues false—And hands shedding innocent blood—

18.text: A heart devising thoughts of vanity—Feet hasting to run to evil—

19.text: A false witness who doth breathe out lies—And one sending forth contentions between brethren.

20.text: Keep, my son, the command of thy father, And leave not the law of thy mother.

21.text: Bind them on thy heart continually, Tie them on thy neck.

22.text: In thy going up and down, it leadeth thee, In thy lying down, it watcheth over thee, And thou hast awaked—it talketh with thee.

23.text: For a lamp is the command, And the law a light, And a way of life are reproofs of instruction,

24.text: To preserve thee from an evil woman, From the flattery of the tongue of a strange woman.

25.text: Desire not her beauty in thy heart, And let her not take thee with her eyelids.

26.text: For a harlot consumeth unto a cake of bread, And an adulteress the precious soul hunteth.

27.text: Doth a man take fire into his bosom, And are his garments not burnt?

28.text: Doth a man walk on the hot coals, And are his feet not scorched?

29.text: So is he who hath gone in unto the wife of his neighbour, None who doth touch her is innocent.

30.text: They do not despise the thief, When he stealeth to fill his soul when he is hungry,

31.text: And being found he repayeth sevenfold, All the substance of his house he giveth.

32.text: He who committeth adultery with a woman lacketh heart, He is destroying his soul who doth it.

33.text: A stroke and shame he doth find, And his reproach is not wiped away,

34.text: For jealousy is the fury of a man, And he doth not spare in a day of vengeance.

35.text: He accepteth not the appearance of any atonement, Yea, he doth not consent, Though thou dost multiply bribes!
